data.title: Juniper upgraded ahead of earnings as potential acquisition by HPE heads to court
data.description:
Juniper Networks (NYSE:JNPR) was upgraded to Outperform from In Line by Evercore ISI ahead of its Q4 2024 earnings report and a looming case by the U.S. Department of Justice regarding a planned $14B acquisition by Hewlett Packard Enterprise (NYSE:HPE).

Evercore believes there is upside to Juniper shareholders regardless of the outcome in the upcoming trial.

"HPE is successful in their bid for JNPR, and JNPR shareholders will end-up with $40/share (15% upside)," said Evercore analysts, led by Amit Daryanani, in a Tuesday investor note. "HPE loses the DOJ trial, JNPR is an independent company, and in that scenario we think there are a host of fundamental levers that would make JNPR a good stock in 2025 – networking recovery, MIST share gains, cloud ramps (xAI and more) + margin expansion."

Regardng the lawsuit, HPE has already received approval for the acquisition by the E.U., United Kingdom, India, South Korea and Australia. However, the U.S. DOJ argues that a merger between HPE and Juniper would minimize competition in the enterprise wireless market.

Juniper is slated to report its fourth quarter results after the bell today. The consensus estimate for adjusted earnings per share is $0.57 on revenue of $1.39B.

data.title: Ball’s shares decline on weaker revenue, quarterly loss
data.description:
Ball’s (NYSE:BALL) stock on Tuesday fell as much as 8.4% after the maker of aluminum cans reported weaker revenue and a quarterly loss.

The packaging company swung to a net loss of $32 million, or $0.11 a share, in the fourth quarter from a profit of $154 million, or $0.49 a share, a year earlier.

Adjusted earnings were $0.84 a share, compared with the average estimate of $0.81 a share among Wall Street analysts.

Sales for the three-month period through December slipped to $2.88 billion from $2.9 billion. Ball (NYSE:BALL) pointed out that sales don’t include the aerospace business it sold a year ago.

Regional results

The company’s packaging business in North and Central America saw sales fall 6.5% to $1.29 billion in the quarter from $1.38 billion a year earlier. Management blamed lower volume and lower price and mix for part of the decline, which was offset somewhat by a contractual pass-through of lower aluminum costs.

In the Europe Middle East Africa region, sales in the beverage packaging segment rose 12% to $826 million from $739 million. In South America, sales fell 8.6% to $563 million from $616 million.

Forward guidance

As for the current year ahead, management estimated comparable earnings per share growth of 10%.

Comparable earnings were $3.17 a share in 2024. Analysts on average forecast earnings of $3.52 a share for 2025.

data.title: Factory orders fall more than expected in December
data.description: U.S. factory orders fell 0.9% M/M to $578.5B in December, the -0.7% consensus and -0.8% in the previous month (revised from -0.4%), according to U.S. Census Bureau data released on Tuesday.

data.title: Hain Celestial's new distribution center to cut delivery times, lower fuel costs
data.description:
As part of the company’s plan to expand its delivery capabilities, increase product availability and lower transportation costs, Hain Celestial (NASDAQ:HAIN) will launch a fourth distribution center in Savannah, Georgia in February.

The new distribution center will enable Hain Celestial (NASDAQ:HAIN) to double its network capacity and minimize delivery distances by 66%, or 2.6 million miles annually.

“By strategically expanding our network, we're significantly enhancing our ability to respond swiftly to market demands and deliver our products more effectively and efficiently to our customers," Hain Celestial Chief Supply Chain Officer Steve Golliher said.

The new distribution center will allow the company to reach more than 90% of its U.S. customers within 1 to 2 days, an increase of 15% from its current capabilities.

The Savannah, Georgia distribution center is an addition to distribution centers in Southern California, Central Pennsylvania, and Chicago.

Hain Celestial (NASDAQ:HAIN) will report fiscal Q2 results on Feb 10, expected to show a profit of $0.12 per share on $431M in sales.

Shares perked up at the open and are 1.7% higher from Monday’s close.

data.title: Supernus stock climbs 5% on FDA approval of Onapgo
data.description:
Shares of Supernus Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:SUPN) rose 5% Tuesday morning on news the FDA has approved its wearable treatment device Onapgo, formerly known as SPN-830, for the treatment of patients with Parkinson's disease.

Supernus (NASDAQ:SUPN) said the decision makes Onapgo the first FDA-approved subcutaneous apomorphine infusion device for the treatment of motor fluctuations in adults with advanced Parkinson’s disease.

The product will be available in the U.S. in the second quarter of 2025.

data.title: Biggest stock movers Tuesday: PLTR, PYPL, SPOT, and more
data.description:
Stock futures were mixed on Tuesday following China's imposition of retaliatory tariffs on U.S. imports, responding to U.S. duties on exports from Beijing. This development occurred as President Donald Trump delayed tariffs on Canada and Mexico by a month after last-minute negotiations with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum.

Here are some of Tuesday's biggest stock movers:

Biggest stock gainers

  • Palantir Technologies (NASDAQ:PLTR) shares surged 22% following its Q4 results, which exceeded expectations with a 36% Y/Y revenue increase, driven by a 64% rise in U.S. commercial revenue and a 45% increase in U.S. government revenue. For Q1, the company projects revenue between $858M and $862M, surpassing the consensus of $810.81M, and adjusted income from operations between $354M and $358M. For FY2025, Palantir anticipates revenue between $3.741B and $3.757B, exceeding the consensus of $3.54B, with U.S. commercial revenue expected to exceed $1.079B, representing at least 54% growth. Adjusted income from operations is projected between $1.551B and $1.567B, and adjusted free cash flow between $1.5B and $1.7B.
  • Spotify's (SPOT) stock surged 10% following a robust earnings report, highlighting a 16% Y/Y revenue increase and a net profit of €367M (€1.76 per share), a significant turnaround from the previous year's €70M loss (-€0.36 per share). Q4 saw premium subscribers rise by 11% to 263M, with an average revenue per user of €4.85, up 5%. Total monthly active users grew by 12% to 675M. Looking ahead, Spotify anticipates adding more users and premium subscribers, forecasting 678M MAUs and 265M premium subscribers in Q1, with expected revenue of €4.2B and a gross margin of 31.5%, all exceeding consensus estimates.

Biggest stock losers

  • Synaptics (NASDAQ:SYNA) shares fell as much as 6% following the announcement that Michael Hurlston is stepping down as President and CEO, effective immediately, to join Lumentum Holdings (LITE) as CEO. Ken Rizvi, the company's CFO, has been appointed interim CEO, and Nelson Chan, Chairman of the Board, will serve as Executive Chairman during the transition. The Board has initiated a search for a permanent CEO, considering both internal and external candidates. Concurrently, Synaptics released preliminary financial results for 2Q25, projecting revenue of approximately $267M, with gross margin in line with the midpoint of prior guidance, operating expenses slightly above the midpoint, and earnings per share exceeding the midpoint of the previous guidance.
  • Diageo (NYSE:DEO) shares declined by 3% following its first-half results, where the company withdrew its medium-term guidance, citing ongoing macroeconomic and geopolitical uncertainties. While confident in long-term industry fundamentals and anticipating organic net sales growth in the second half of fiscal 2025, Diageo provided a more cautious outlook, including an expected pre-exceptional tax rate of around 24%, a stable effective interest rate of 4.3%, capital expenditures toward the upper end of the $1.3B–$1.5B range, and leverage exceeding its target range of 2.5–3.0x.
  • Although PayPal (PYPL) exceeded expectations in Q4, its shares fell more than 8% due to a decline in GAAP operating margin by 431 basis points to 17.2% and a 34 basis point decrease in non-GAAP operating margin to 18.0%. This overshadowed a promising profit outlook for 2025. For Q1, the company provided EPS guidance of $1.15 to $1.17, compared to the consensus of $1.13, and FY2025 EPS guidance is set between $4.95 and $5.10, slightly above the consensus of $4.90. Additionally, the company announced a new $15B stock repurchase program.
  • Merck's (MRK) shares plunged nearly 11% after the company issued a FY2025 outlook that fell short of market expectations and announced a temporary suspension of Gardasil vaccine shipments to China until at least mid-year. The company projects 2025 global sales between $64.1B and $65.6B, below the consensus of $67.36B, and adjusted EPS ranging from $8.88 to $9.03, missing the consensus of $9.23.

data.title: McDonald's bring back Uncle O'Grimacey after 40 years as its sales-driven trip down memory lane continues
data.description:
McDonald's Corporation (NYSE:MCD) continues to lean on nostalgia as a sales driver after the return of the Grimace Birthday Meal, the launch of CosMc's, and the use of Hamburglar in promotions again all created viral buzz.

Next in line is Uncle O'Grimacey, who is Grimace's Irish uncle and has not been seen in a few decades. Uncle O'Grimacey shares a similar shape to his nephew Grimace, featuring a round body with short arms and legs.

In terms of the menu, the restaurant operator said the Shamrock Shake, a milkshake made with vanilla soft-serve ice cream, mint-flavored green syrup and whipped topping, will return to restaurants on February 10. The Shamrock Shake has been on McDonald's seasonal menu for more than 50 years. In addition, the Oreo Shamrock McFlurry, made with vanilla soft-serve, minty green syrup and Oreo cookie pieces, will also be on the menu.

As part of a promotion that runs from February 10 to March 23, every Shamrock Shake sold at participating McDonald's (NYSE:MCD) will see $0.25 go to Ronald McDonald House Charities, with a goal of raising $5 million. That campaign also features new Uncle O'Grimacey merchandise, available exclusively at Golden Arches Unlimited, purchases of which will lead to more to Ronald McDonald House Charities.

Looking ahead, McDonald's (NYSE:MCD) is lined up to report Q4 earnings on February 10. Analysts expect revenue of $6.5 billion and EPS of $2.86 to be disclosed.

Shares of McDonald's (MCD) were up 0.1% in early trading and are essentially flat for the year.
